Depictions of the Conquistadors in popular media have evolved significantly over time. Initially, the Conquistadors were portrayed as heroic figures who conquered foreign lands and brought civilization, Christianity, and prosperity to the native people they encountered. They were portrayed as brave warriors who fought against savage tribes to bring a higher culture to the New World.

However, in more recent times, the depiction of the Conquistadors has become more nuanced and complex. They are no longer portrayed as the unambiguous heroes of history. Instead, they are often portrayed as ruthless conquerors who committed atrocities against the indigenous people they encountered. They are shown as taking land and resources from the native peoples, and forcing them to convert to Christianity at the point of a sword.

This shift in popular media is due in part to changing attitudes towards imperialism and colonialism. As people have become more aware of the negative impacts that imperialism and colonialism have had on indigenous populations, the Conquistadors have become more closely associated with these negative forces. Additionally, as a new generation of scholars has emerged with a more critical approach to history, the depiction of the Conquistadors has become more nuanced and multifaceted.

In summary, depictions of the Conquistadors have evolved from a heroic portrayal in earlier times to a more complex and nuanced depiction in more recent popular media. This shift reflects changing attitudes towards imperialism, a more critical approach to history, and a desire for a more accurate representation of the past.
